metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Zhangye wetland station, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Zhangye wetland station eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2021. The site (100.44640° E, 38.97514° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1460 m. The EC was installed at a height of 5.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (Gill&Li7500A) was 0.25 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a data collection method used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, which includes energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. It is instrumental in understanding the exchanges of these elements in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'data processing and quality control procedure' in hydrometeorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Data processing and quality control procedure refers to the steps involved in data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This procedure ensures the reliability and accuracy of hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, and other environmental parameters.

Definition.Question: How is 'oasis–desert system' defined in the context of ecological and socioeconomic research?
Definition.Answer: An oasis–desert system is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas, crucial for maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity. It plays a significant role in carbon balance and supports the socioeconomic development of oases, particularly in western China.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing and quality control procedures between datasets collected in arid inland river basins and those from other climate regions?
Comparison.Answer: In arid inland river basins, data processing involves specific steps like despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, and various corrections for frequency response and density effects. Quality control includes screening for instrument errors and data gaps. These procedures may differ from other climate regions where atmospheric conditions and environmental factors vary, possibly requiring different corrections and quality assessments.

Comparison.Question: How does the integration of hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters in oasis-desert systems compare to other ecosystems in terms of dataset comprehensiveness and utility?
Comparison.Answer: In oasis-desert systems, datasets integrate hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters to provide a comprehensive view of ecosystem dynamics, aiding in understanding energy, water, and carbon exchanges. This integration may differ in other ecosystems where the focus might be more on specific parameters like soil moisture or vegetation type, depending on the primary environmental challenges and research goals of those ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: How do the methodological steps such as coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction in data processing influence the quality and accuracy of flux measurements in wetland ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The methodological steps like coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction are crucial in ensuring the accuracy of flux measurements. Coordinate rotation aligns the data with the mean wind direction, minimizing errors due to misalignment. Frequency response correction adjusts for losses in high-frequency data capture, improving the signal fidelity. Density correction accounts for temperature and pressure variations, ensuring that the fluxes are accurately quantified. These steps collectively enhance the quality of the processed data, making them reliable for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics in wetland ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining long-term data collection networks in arid and semi-arid regions, and how can these be mitigated to ensure consistent data quality?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining long-term data collection networks in arid and semi-arid regions include ecological degradation, such as drying rivers and intensified desertification, which can affect instrumentation and data continuity. Mitigating these challenges involves regular maintenance of equipment, strategic siting of observation stations to avoid extreme conditions, and employing robust data processing techniques to handle any gaps or errors in the data. Ensuring local community involvement and integrating remote sensing data can also provide supplementary insights and improve the resilience of data collection efforts.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of auxiliary data, such as vegetation and soil parameters, enhance the interpretation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of auxiliary data, such as vegetation and soil parameters, provides a more comprehensive understanding of the factors influencing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems. Vegetation data can inform on the photosynthetic activity and water use efficiency, while soil parameters reveal insights into moisture retention and heat fluxes. This holistic approach allows for more accurate modeling of ecological interactions and supports the assessment of ecosystem resilience and sustainability in these regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in data collection efforts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining a balance is crucial to achieve sustainable oasis development and to understand the interactions between oasis and desert systems. This balance helps support ecological security and socioeconomic development while contributing to goals like carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying challenges in collecting long-term observational datasets in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges include environmental degradation issues such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, desertification, and frequent dust storms, which complicate the collection and maintenance of long-term datasets in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing a 10Hz sampling frequency in eddy covariance systems on the quality and reliability of flux data in wetland ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a 10Hz sampling frequency in eddy covariance systems allows for high-resolution data that can capture detailed turbulence characteristics necessary for accurate flux measurements. This high frequency enables more precise delay time corrections, coordinate rotation, and frequency response adjustments, leading to improved data quality and reliability for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in wetland ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the application of data processing steps such as coordinate rotation and frequency response correction affect the interpretation of energy and carbon flux data in arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of data processing steps like coordinate rotation and frequency response correction is crucial for refining the raw data obtained from eddy covariance systems. These steps help minimize errors associated with misalignment and sensor response issues, thereby enhancing the accuracy of energy and carbon flux interpretation. This is particularly important in arid and semiarid regions where precise measurements are needed to understand the complex interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific steps involved in processing eddy covariance data to ensure its quality and usability in hydrometeorological observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing of eddy covariance data involves steps such as despiking to remove outliers, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and WPL density correction. Quality evaluation of flux values is performed through tests for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Additionally, data is filtered to remove periods of instrument error, data surrounding precipitation events, and data with more than 10% missing values in 10Hz raw data over 30 minutes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to ensure the quality control and validation of flux measurements in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methodologies for quality control and validation include the application of Eddypro software to process raw data into 30-minute averages, with specific quality control steps such as despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, and various corrections for response, temperature, and density. The quality of the processed flux data is further evaluated through atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity tests, and data is selectively filtered based on instrument errors, precipitation events, and data loss criteria.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of Eddypro software enhance the processing and quality control of turbulent flux data collected from eddy covariance systems?
Enablement.Answer: Eddypro software enhances the processing and quality control of turbulent flux data by performing steps such as outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction, alongside quality evaluation based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Enablement.Answer: Effective land surface flux and meteorological stations in arid regions require technological setups such as eddy covariance systems with specified configurations, automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data, and the capability for long-term monitoring. The environmental conditions include situating stations in regions that represent typical oasis-desert interactions, as well as ensuring the availability of auxiliary data for comprehensive analysis.
